title: Diversity and habitat preference of butterflies in Shivapuri-Nagarjun National Park, Kathmandu
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A study to assess the species richness and distribution patterns of butterflies across different habitat types (e.g., forest, open areas, streamside) within the national park.
suitability: Highly suitable for B.Sc/M.Sc students in Kathmandu. Requires only basic field equipment (net, camera, GPS) and identification keys. The park is easily accessible, and previous studies provide a good baseline.
main_methods: Line transect method, Pollard walk, basic morphological identification using field guides and keys, GPS mapping of transects.
possible_sites: Shivapuri-Nagarjun National Park (Sundarijal, Budhanilkantha, Kakani sectors).

key_references.title: A checklist of butterflies of Shivapuri-Nagarjun National Park, Nepal
Butterfly diversity in the Kathmandu Valley, Nepal

title: Assessment of water quality and macro-invertebrate diversity in the Bagmati River (Kirtipur section)
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Investigating the correlation between physicochemical parameters of the river water (pH, DO, BOD, etc.) and the diversity and abundance of benthic macro-invertebrates, which serve as bio-indicators of water health.
suitability: A classic and highly relevant topic for environmental zoology in Nepal. Requires basic water quality testing kits and a microscope for invertebrate identification. Fieldwork is easily manageable.
main_methods: Standard water quality analysis (titration, probe-based), Surber sampler or kick-net for macro-invertebrate collection, morphological identification using keys.
possible_sites: Various sampling points along the Bagmati River near Kirtipur and Chobhar.

key_references.title: Macro-invertebrates as bio-indicators of water quality in the Bagmati River, Nepal
Physico-chemical characteristics of the Bagmati River
key_references.source: Nepal Journal of Science and Technology

title: Prevalence of gastrointestinal parasites in domestic dogs of Pokhara Metropolitan City
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A survey-based study to determine the types and infection rates of common helminth and protozoan parasites in the fecal samples of domestic dogs, with implications for public health.
suitability: Excellent B.Sc. project. Requires only basic microscopy and simple flotation/sedimentation techniques. Samples are easy to collect, and the topic has direct public health relevance.
main_methods: Fecal sample collection, direct smear, simple flotation technique (e.g., saturated salt solution), morphological identification of eggs/cysts under a microscope.
possible_sites: Veterinary clinics, animal shelters, and various wards of Pokhara.

key_references.title: Zoonotic helminths in stray dogs of Nepal: a public health concern
key_references.source: Journal of Veterinary Science and Medicine

key_references.title: Prevalence of gastrointestinal parasites in dogs in Pokhara, Nepal

title: Ethological study of feeding behavior in captive One-horned Rhinoceros (Rhinoceros unicornis) at Chitwan National Park
description: Observational study to quantify the time budget and feeding patterns of captive rhinos, focusing on diurnal variation and preference for different fodder types.
suitability: A good B.Sc. project focusing on observational skills. Requires no lab work, only field observation and data recording. Chitwan is the primary site for this species.
main_methods: Focal animal sampling, scan sampling, ethogram development, direct observation, and time budget analysis.
possible_sites: Captive breeding centers or protected areas within Chitwan National Park.

key_references.title: Time budget and activity patterns of the greater one-horned rhinoceros in Nepal
Feeding ecology of the greater one-horned rhinoceros in Chitwan National Park

title: Diversity and abundance of avifauna in a selected urban park in Kathmandu Valley
description: A comparative study of bird species richness and abundance in an urban green space versus a nearby residential area to assess the impact of urbanization on avian diversity.
suitability: Feasible for both B.Sc and M.Sc. students. Requires only binoculars, a field guide, and basic statistical analysis. The study site is easily accessible.
main_methods: Point count method, line transect method, visual and auditory identification, use of field guides.
possible_sites: Godawari Botanical Garden, Tribhuvan University premises, or a large public park in Kathmandu.

key_references.title: Avian diversity in urban green spaces of Kathmandu, Nepal
key_references.source: Journal of Ecology and Natural Resources

key_references.title: Bird species richness and abundance in different habitats of Kathmandu Valley

title: Impact of traditional fishing practices on non-target fish species in the Fewa Lake, Pokhara
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Analyzing the catch composition of local fishermen to quantify the bycatch of non-commercial or threatened fish species and assess the sustainability of current fishing methods.
suitability: A strong M.Sc. topic with conservation implications. Requires collaboration with local fishermen and basic fish identification skills. No advanced lab work is needed.
main_methods: Interview-based surveys with fishermen, direct observation of catch, morphological identification of fish species, basic statistical analysis of catch data.
possible_sites: Fewa Lake and surrounding fish landing sites in Pokhara.

key_references.title: Fisheries and conservation status of indigenous fish species in Fewa Lake, Nepal
Assessment of fishing gears and their impact on fish diversity in Fewa Lake
key_references.source: Nepal Journal of Science and Technology

title: Distribution and conservation status of the Himalayan Pit Viper (Gloydius himalayanus) in the Mid-hills of Nepal
description: Field survey to map the distribution range of the Himalayan Pit Viper and assess threats to its population from habitat loss and human-snake conflict.
suitability: A challenging but rewarding M.Sc. project. Requires extensive fieldwork and knowledge of herpetological survey techniques. Focuses on a less-studied group.
main_methods: Visual Encounter Survey (VES), opportunistic searching, GPS mapping of sightings, interview surveys with local communities.
possible_sites: Selected forest patches in the Mid-hills region (e.g., Langtang National Park buffer zone).

key_references.title: Distribution and diversity of snakes in the Mid-hills of Nepal
Conservation status of venomous snakes in Nepal

title: Diversity of soil mites (Acari) in different land-use types (forest, agriculture, fallow) in Western Nepal
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A comparative study to assess how different land management practices affect the species richness and abundance of soil mites, which are important indicators of soil health.
suitability: A strong M.Sc. topic that requires detailed lab work (microscopy) but no advanced equipment. Focuses on a less-explored area of zoology in Nepal.
main_methods: Berlese-Tullgren funnel extraction of soil samples, slide preparation, morphological identification under a compound microscope.
possible_sites: Agricultural and forest areas in the Palpa or Syangja districts of Western Nepal.

key_references.title: Soil microarthropod diversity in different ecosystems of Nepal
Impact of land use change on soil mite communities in the Himalayas

title: Human-wildlife conflict assessment: Crop raiding by Rhesus Macaques (Macaca mulatta) in the Mid-hills
description: Investigating the patterns and factors driving crop raiding by Rhesus Macaques, quantifying the economic loss, and assessing local community attitudes towards the species.
suitability: A highly relevant and feasible topic. Requires social surveys (questionnaires) and direct field observation. Excellent for B.Sc. or M.Sc. students interested in applied conservation.
main_methods: Questionnaire surveys, direct observation of raiding incidents, crop damage assessment (quadrat method), basic statistical analysis.
possible_sites: Villages bordering forests in the Mid-hills (e.g., Kavrepalanchok, Sindhupalchok).

key_references.title: Human-macaque conflict in Nepal: a case study from the Mid-hills
Assessment of crop damage by wildlife in Nepal

title: Diversity and distribution of freshwater crabs (Decapoda: Brachyura) in the Pokhara Valley streams
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A survey to document the species of freshwater crabs in the streams and rivers of Pokhara Valley and analyze their distribution in relation to stream habitat characteristics.
suitability: A focused and manageable project. Crabs are relatively easy to collect and identify using morphological features. Suitable for B.Sc. or a focused M.Sc. project.
main_methods: Hand collection, trapping, morphological identification using taxonomic keys, habitat characterization (substrate, flow rate, vegetation).
possible_sites: Seti River tributaries and various streams around Pokhara.

key_references.title: Freshwater crabs of Nepal: a checklist and distribution
Diversity and ecology of freshwater crabs in the Gandaki River Basin, Nepal

title: Ectoparasite load and body condition of House Sparrows (Passer domesticus) in Kathmandu urban areas
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Investigating the relationship between the abundance of ectoparasites (e.g., mites, lice) and the body condition (e.g., weight, wing length) of House Sparrows in different urban microhabitats.
suitability: A practical and ethical B.Sc. project. Requires mist-netting (with proper permits/supervision) and basic lab work for parasite identification. High relevance to urban ecology.
main_methods: Mist-netting (catch and release), visual inspection for ectoparasites, basic morphometric measurements, microscopic identification of parasites.
possible_sites: TU premises, public parks, and residential areas in Kathmandu.

key_references.title: Ectoparasites of birds in Nepal: a review
Impact of ectoparasites on the body condition of urban birds

title: Comparative study of plankton diversity in two different fish ponds in Chitwan
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Comparing the species richness and abundance of phytoplankton and zooplankton in two fish ponds with different management practices (e.g., fertilized vs. unfertilized).
suitability: An excellent B.Sc. project for students interested in aquaculture. Requires simple plankton net collection and microscopy. Fieldwork is straightforward.
main_methods: Plankton net collection, sample preservation, microscopic counting and identification using keys, basic water quality measurements.
possible_sites: Commercial or university-managed fish farms in the Chitwan area.

key_references.title: Plankton diversity in aquaculture ponds of Nepal
Impact of fertilization on plankton community structure in fish ponds

title: Morphometric analysis of the Common Wall Lizard (L. muralis) populations across an altitudinal gradient in the Mid-hills
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Measuring various body dimensions of the lizard from different altitudes to determine if there are significant morphological variations (e.g., Bergmann's or Allen's rule) due to environmental factors.
suitability: A classic M.Sc. project in evolutionary ecology. Requires careful fieldwork and precise measurement skills. No advanced lab work is required.
main_methods: Visual Encounter Survey (VES), capture and release, digital caliper measurements, photographic documentation, basic statistical analysis (ANOVA, regression).
possible_sites: Selected transects in the Mid-hills ranging from 1000m to 2500m.

key_references.title: Altitudinal variation in the morphology of lizards in the Himalayas
key_references.source: Biological Journal of the Linnean Society

key_references.title: Morphometric analysis of Lacertidae species in Nepal

title: Diversity and distribution of spiders (Arachnida: Araneae) in the agricultural fields of Western Nepal
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Surveying spider species in different crop fields to assess their role as natural pest control agents and how farming practices affect their diversity.
suitability: A good project for students interested in agricultural entomology/ecology. Requires pitfall traps and hand collection, followed by detailed microscopy.
main_methods: Pitfall trapping, hand collection, sweep netting, morphological identification under a stereomicroscope.
possible_sites: Rice, maize, and vegetable fields in the Rupandehi or Kapilvastu districts.

key_references.title: Spider fauna of agricultural ecosystems in Nepal
Role of spiders in pest control in Nepalese agriculture
key_references.source: Nepal Journal of Science and Technology

title: Conservation awareness and attitude of local people towards the Red Panda (Ailurus fulgens) in Eastern Nepal
description: A social survey to evaluate the level of knowledge, awareness, and conservation attitudes of local communities living near Red Panda habitats, which is crucial for community-based conservation.
suitability: A feasible and impactful project. Primarily relies on social science methods (questionnaires, interviews). Requires good communication skills and field access.
main_methods: Structured questionnaire surveys, Key Informant Interviews (KIIs), Focus Group Discussions (FGDs), basic descriptive statistics.
possible_sites: Villages in the Ilam or Panchthar districts, known Red Panda habitats.

key_references.title: Community-based conservation of Red Panda in Eastern Nepal
Assessment of local people's attitudes towards Red Panda conservation

title: Study of the feeding ecology of the Common Leopard (Panthera pardus) through scat analysis in the Mid-hills forest
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Analyzing the contents of leopard scats to determine their diet composition, focusing on the proportion of wild prey versus domestic animals, which informs conflict mitigation strategies.
suitability: A classic M.Sc. project. Requires extensive fieldwork for scat collection and basic lab work for hair/bone fragment identification (microscopy).
main_methods: Systematic scat collection along transects, washing and drying of scat, microscopic identification of hair and bone fragments using reference slides.
possible_sites: Forest areas near human settlements in the Mid-hills (e.g., Mahabharat range).

key_references.title: Diet composition of Common Leopard in Nepal: a review
Scat analysis for diet determination of carnivores in the Himalayas

title: Impact of solid waste dumping on the diversity of houseflies (Musca domestica) and associated public health risks in Kathmandu
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Quantifying the population density of houseflies near waste disposal sites and assessing the potential for pathogen transmission by culturing bacteria from their body surfaces.
suitability: A highly practical B.Sc. project with direct public health relevance. Requires simple trapping methods and basic microbiology lab techniques (culturing, staining, microscopy).
main_methods: Sticky trap method for fly collection, morphological identification, bacterial culture on nutrient agar, Gram staining, and microscopy.
possible_sites: Selected solid waste dumping sites and nearby residential areas in Kathmandu.

key_references.title: Role of houseflies in mechanical transmission of pathogens in Nepal
Impact of solid waste on insect diversity in urban areas

title: Assessment of fish diversity and abundance in the tributaries of the Karnali River in Western Nepal
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A survey to document the ichthyofaunal diversity and assess the relative abundance of different fish species in the less-explored tributaries of the Karnali River system.
suitability: A strong M.Sc. project in ichthyology. Requires extensive fieldwork and fish identification skills. No advanced lab work is required.
main_methods: Electro-fishing (if permitted and available) or cast-netting, morphological identification using taxonomic keys, habitat characterization.
possible_sites: Selected tributaries of the Karnali River in the Bardiya or Kailali districts.

key_references.title: Ichthyofaunal diversity of the Karnali River Basin, Nepal
Status of indigenous fish species in the rivers of Western Nepal

title: Seasonal variation in the abundance of mosquitoes (Culicidae) and their breeding habitats in the Chitwan area
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Monitoring the population dynamics of medically important mosquito species and identifying their preferred breeding sites in different seasons, which is vital for vector control.
suitability: A highly practical and relevant project. Requires simple trapping (e.g., light traps, ovitraps) and basic lab work for species identification (microscopy).
main_methods: Larval collection from breeding sites, adult collection using light traps, morphological identification of species under a microscope, basic statistical analysis of seasonal data.
possible_sites: Residential areas and forest fringes in the Chitwan district.

key_references.title: Mosquito species diversity and their breeding habitats in the Terai region of Nepal
Seasonal prevalence of Aedes and Anopheles mosquitoes in Chitwan

title: Inventory of bat species and their roosting sites in the caves of Pokhara Valley
description: A survey to document the species richness of bats and characterize the physical and environmental features of their roosting sites in the limestone caves of Pokhara.
suitability: A good M.Sc. project. Requires specialized field techniques (e.g., mist-netting at cave entrances, with proper permits/supervision) and morphological identification. Focuses on a key faunal group.
main_methods: Mist-netting (catch and release), acoustic monitoring (if budget allows, otherwise visual/photographic), morphological identification using keys, habitat characterization.
possible_sites: Mahendra Cave, Bat Cave, and other limestone caves in the Pokhara area.

key_references.title: Bat diversity and conservation in the caves of Nepal
Roosting ecology of bats in the Pokhara Valley

title: Study of the nesting behavior and success of the Oriental Magpie-Robin (Copsychus saularis) in urban Kathmandu
description: Observational study to document the nesting site selection, clutch size, hatching success, and fledging success of the Oriental Magpie-Robin in different urban settings.
suitability: A manageable and interesting project. Requires consistent field observation and data recording. Suitable for B.Sc. or M.Sc. students interested in behavioral ecology.
main_methods: Systematic nest searching, direct observation, recording of behavioral data, calculation of nesting success (Mayfield method).
possible_sites: Residential gardens, university campuses, and public parks in Kathmandu.

key_references.title: Breeding biology of the Oriental Magpie-Robin in Nepal
Nesting success of urban birds in the Kathmandu Valley

title: Effect of different organic manures on the growth and reproduction of the earthworm (Eisenia fetida) in vermicomposting
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: An experimental study to compare the growth rate, biomass, and cocoon production of the earthworm *Eisenia fetida* when fed different types of organic waste (e.g., cow dung, vegetable waste).
suitability: An excellent, low-cost, and practical B.Sc. project. Requires basic lab setup and simple weighing/counting. High relevance to sustainable agriculture.
main_methods: Controlled experimental setup (pots/bins), regular weighing and counting of earthworms and cocoons, basic statistical analysis.
possible_sites: Any college or home with a small experimental space.

key_references.title: Vermicomposting technology in Nepal: a review

key_references.title: Growth and reproduction of Eisenia fetida on different organic wastes

title: Diversity and distribution of freshwater turtles (Testudines) in the Chitwan National Park and its buffer zone
description: A field survey to document the species of freshwater turtles and assess their population status and threats in the aquatic habitats of the national park and surrounding areas.
suitability: A strong M.Sc. project with high conservation value. Requires extensive fieldwork and knowledge of turtle survey techniques (e.g., basking surveys, trapping).
main_methods: Visual Encounter Survey (VES), basking surveys, hoop-net trapping, morphological identification, GPS mapping of sightings.

key_references.title: Status and distribution of freshwater turtles in Nepal

title: Study of the foraging behavior of the Honey Bee (Apis cerana) in relation to floral resources in the Mid-hills
description: Observational study to quantify the foraging rate, flower constancy, and preferred floral species of the native honey bee, which is important for local beekeeping and pollination services.
suitability: A manageable and highly practical project. Requires consistent field observation and basic plant identification skills. Suitable for B.Sc. or M.Sc. students.
main_methods: Direct observation, time budget analysis, pollen analysis (if basic lab is available), recording of floral species visited.
possible_sites: Apiaries and surrounding forest/agricultural areas in the Mid-hills.

key_references.title: Foraging behavior of Apis cerana in the Mid-hills of Nepal
Floral resources and honey production in Nepal

title: Assessment of heavy metal contamination in the tissues of common fish species from the Bishnumati River, Kathmandu
methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: Collecting common fish species and analyzing their muscle and liver tissues for the presence and concentration of heavy metals (e.g., Lead, Cadmium). *Note: This requires access to an external lab for AAS/ICP-MS, but the student's role is sample collection, preparation, and basic analysis/interpretation.*
suitability: A strong M.Sc. project with public health relevance. The most challenging part is the chemical analysis, which is often outsourced or done in collaboration with a central lab (TU/NAST). The student focuses on field sampling and data interpretation.
main_methods: Fish collection (netting), tissue dissection and preservation, sample preparation (digestion), data interpretation from external lab reports.
possible_sites: Bishnumati River and its confluence points in Kathmandu.

key_references.title: Heavy metal accumulation in fish from the rivers of Kathmandu Valley
Bioaccumulation of heavy metals in aquatic organisms in Nepal

suitability: A manageable project. Requires simple trapping methods (e.g., Sherman traps) and morphological identification. Suitable for B.Sc. or M.Sc. students.

key_references.title: Gastrointestinal parasites of captive wild animals in Nepal

methods_allowed: Basic lab only (microscope, preservatives, field gear)
description: A survey to document the species of medicinal leeches and assess their population status and habitat characteristics in the wetlands of Eastern Nepal, which are under threat.

title: Assessment of the impact of road traffic noise on the calling behavior of the Common Toad (Duttaphrynus melanostictus) in Pokhara

title: Impact of traditional grazing practices on the diversity of dung beetles (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) in the Mid-hills

main_methods: Hand collection, scoop netting, morphological identification using taxonomic keys, habitat characterization.

title: Study of the diversity and abundance of aquatic insects (e.g., Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera, Trichoptera) in the streams of the Mid-hills

main_methods: Line transect method, point count method, direct observation, interview surveys with local communities.
